Statistics 1: Problem Sheet5 The Likelihood

6 The Bayesian Paradigm

Priors, Posteriors and Conjugacy

  1. 39.

    Suppose that the probability θ of producing a defective item in an automated manufacturing process is unknown.

    1. (a)

      A sample of n=8 items are to be selected at random. The total number of this sample found to be defective is represented as X. What is the distribution of X?

    2. (b)

      It is found that X=3 of the n=8 items are indeed defective. Write down the likelihood function ℓ⁢(θ).

    3. (c)

      Suppose the prior distribution of θ is a uniform distribution on the interval [0,1]. Determine the posterior distribution of θ, up to a multiplicative constant, using Bayes theorem for continuous variables.

    4. (d)

      Find the mode of the posterior distribution i.e. the value of θ that maximises the posterior distribution. This is often called the Maximum A Posteriori (MAP) estimate and denoted θ^M⁢A⁢P. Compare with the θ^M⁢L⁢E and comment.

    5. (e)

      Now suppose that the prior pdf for θ is instead f⁢(θ)=2⁢(1−θ) for 0≤θ≤1, and 0 otherwise. As before, suppose that three out of eight items are found to be defective. Determine the posterior distribution for θ, up to a multiplicative constant.

    6. (f)

      Find the MAP estimate θ^M⁢A⁢P in this case and compare with your answer to part (d).

  2. 40.

    [Exam standard] Consider the same scenario as in question 39., but now for the general case where n items are to be selected at random, and X=x are found to be defective.

    1. (a)

      Write down the likelihood function ℓ⁢(θ).

    2. (b)

      Suppose the prior distribution for θ was that of a Beta distribution with parameters a and b, that is θ∼B⁢e⁢t⁢a⁢(a,b). Show that this Beta distribution is conjugate for the likelihood you gave in part (a). [Reminder: a prior is conjugate if the posterior turns out to belong to the same family of distributions as the prior.]

    3. (c)

      Give the full posterior pdf for θ, including an expression for the multiplicative constant.

    4. (d)

      Which Beta distributions do the two priors used in question 39. correspond to?

    5. (e)

      Give the full posterior pdfs, including evaluating the multiplicative constants, corresponding to the two priors in Question 39.. Note, this will involve evaluating Gamma functions and remembering that Γ⁢(a)=(a−1)! for positive integer a.

    6. (f)

      For the general prior case θ∼B⁢e⁢t⁢a⁢(a,b) give the prior and posterior expectations of θ. Compare them and comment.

    7. (g)

      What is the behaviour of the posterior expectation as n→∞?

  3. 41.

    Suppose that the number of minutes X that a person must wait for a bus each morning has a uniform distribution on the interval [0,θ], where the value of the endpoint θ is unknown. So we have X|θ∼U⁢[0,θ].

    1. (a)

      Sketch a plot of the conditional pdf of X given θ, that is plot f⁢(x|θ) against x, clearly labelling θ.

    2. (b)

      If a single waiting time observation x1 is obtained, write down the likelihood ℓ⁢(θ) as a function of θ, remembering to specify clearly the values of θ for which the likelihood will be zero. [Hint: Uniform distributions over arbitrary ranges still have to integrate to 1.]

    3. (c)

      Sketch a plot of the likelihood ℓ⁢(θ) against θ, carefully labelling the location of x1.

    4. (d)

      Suppose that the prior pdf of θ is as follows:

      f⁢(θ)={192θ4for⁢θ≥4,0otherwise.

      If observed waiting times on three successive mornings are (5,3,8) minutes, what is the posterior pdf of θ?

  4. 42.

    [Exam standard] A Weibull distribution (with shape parameter fixed at the value 2), with scale parameter α>0, for a non-negative continuous random quantity X, has probability density function

    f⁢(x∣α)=2⁢α2⁢x⁢e−(α⁢x)2
    1. (a)

      Assume that n observations x1, … , xn are sampled from this distribution. Derive the likelihood function for α based on these data, and also derive the corresponding maximum likelihood estimate of α.

    2. (b)

      Show that conjugate priors for α can be specified by the probability density function

      f⁢(a)∝a2⁢ν⁢e−τ⁢a2

      for a>0 and with ν>0 and τ>0. Specify (up to proportionality constant) the corresponding posterior density function based on the observations x1,…,xn. Derive the modes of these prior and posterior distributions, and briefly discuss how the posterior mode relates to the mode of the prior distribution and the maximum likelihood estimate of α.

    3. (c)

      Explain carefully how one could interpret the parameters ν and τ of these prior distributions in part (b) in relation to sufficient statistics of the data.

    4. (d)

      Suppose that, in addition to the n observations x1, …, xn, for one further individual it was observed that the corresponding random value Xn+1>c, for some c>0, so not its actual value was observed but only that it exceeds c. Is it important to take this information into account? If so, briefly explain how one can take it into account when one uses the methods of parts (a) and (b). If you consider it not important that this information is taken into account, briefly explain why not.

  5. 43.

    We saw the definition of the Beta distribution in lectures:

    Let X∼Beta⁢(a,b) for a,b>0 known. Then X has a Beta distribution with pdf

    f⁢(x)=1B⁢(a,b)⁢xa−1⁢(1−x)b−1=Γ⁢(a+b)Γ⁢(a)⁢Γ⁢(b)⁢xa−1⁢(1−x)b−1,0≤x≤1

    and 0 otherwise, where B⁢(a,b)=Γ⁢(a)⁢Γ⁢(b)Γ⁢(a+b) is the Beta function, Γ⁢(a) is the Gamma function and Γ⁢(a)=(a−1)! for a∈ℕ. The Gamma function also satisfies the more general statement Γ⁢(a+1)=a⁢Γ⁢(a) for a∈ℝ,a>0, which you will need.

    1. (a)

      Using the fact that, if X∼Beta⁢(a,b) then f⁢(x) must integrate to 1, show that the expectation of X is given by:

      E⁢[X]=aa+b
    2. (b)

      Similarly, find E⁢[X2].

    3. (c)

      Hence, show that:

      Var⁢[X]=a⁢b(a+b)2⁢(a+b+1)
    4. (d)

      Show that the mode, i.e. the value of x that maximises f⁢(x), is indeed given by:

      M⁢o⁢d⁢e⁢(X)=a−1a+b−2 for ⁢a,b>1

Credible Intervals and the Normal-Normal Model

  1. 44.

    [Exam standard] Now we have learned a lot more about updating our beliefs about probabilities, we can advise the student in Question 1. She was told that she is about to play a game against an opponent who is a cheat, using a loaded dice which rolls a 6 more often than not. Let’s focus on just the events that a 6 is rolled or it is not, so we redefine: Xi=1: a 6 is rolled, and Xi=0: a 6 was not rolled, for the ith roll. The total number of times a 6 is rolled out of n rolls is denoted X=∑i=1nXi as usual and we see that X|p∼B⁢i⁢n⁢(n,p) where p=P⁢(Xi=1), the probability that a 6 is rolled on any individual roll.

    1. (a)

      The student had originally (in Question 1(b)) asserted that p=0.6 in response to the information that the dice “rolls a 6 more often than not”, but now realises that such a precise statement is somewhat dangerous. She instead wants to specify a Beta prior distribution for p that has

      E⁢[p]=0.6andVar⁢[p]=0.052

      implying that a prior interval of E⁢[p]±2⁢SD⁢[p]=[0.5,0.7]. Assuming p∼B⁢e⁢t⁢a⁢(a,b), find a and b to ensure this prior is consistent with her specified expectation and variance.

    2. (b)

      If she then plays the game and sees a total of x 6’s from a set of n rolls of the dice, write down the posterior distribution for p both for this general case, and for the case in Question 1(c) where n=1000 and x=550.

    3. (c)

      For the n=1000 and x=550 case give the posterior expectation E⁢[p|x], variance Var⁢[p|x] and standard deviation SD[p|x].

    4. (d)

      One has to wait a long time to see 1000 rolls of the dice. Write down her posterior after only n=50 rolls, when she has seen x=27 rolls that gave a 6. Calculate a 95% Credible Interval in this case using the normal approximation to the Beta distribution (which will be very accurate here).

    5. (e)

      Calculate the corresponding frequentist 95% Confidence Interval for the n=50 and x=27 case and compare to the Credible Interval found in part (d). What is the relative width of these intervals?

    6. (f)

      Examine the behaviour of the posterior variance Var⁢[p|x] for large n (i.e. when n and therefore x become large, but where n has not reached ∞), for constant a and b.

    7. (g)

      Hence, examine the behaviour of the 95% Credible Interval for large n (your answer to Q40(g) may help). Compare this behaviour to the 95% Confidence Interval and comment.

  2. 45.

    [Exam standard] Suppose that y1,…,yn is a random sample from a uniform distribution on (0,θ) where θ is an unknown positive parameter.

    1. (a)

      Show that the likelihood function ℓ⁢(θ) is given by ℓ⁢(θ)=1/θn for m<θ<∞ and 0 otherwise, where m=max⁡{y1,…,yn}.

    2. (b)

      Suppose that the prior distribution for θ is a Pareto distribution

      f⁢(θ)={a⁢baθa+1b<θ<∞0otherwise

      where a and b are specified positive constants. Show that the posterior distribution for θ is also Pareto with constants a+n and max⁡{b,m}.

    3. (c)

      Now put a=b=0 in the posterior distribution (corresponding to “vague” prior beliefs), and with this specification show that (m,m⁢α−1/n) is the 100⁢(1−α)% highest posterior density (HPD) credible interval for θ; that is, the posterior density at any point inside the interval is greater than that of any point outside the interval.

  3. 46.

    A random sample of n students is drawn from a large population, and their weights measured. The average weight of the n sampled students is x¯=150 pounds. Assume the weights in the population are normally distributed with unknown mean μ and known standard deviation 20 pounds. Suppose your prior distribution for μ is normal with mean 180 and standard deviation 40.

    1. (a)

      What is your posterior distribution for μ in terms of n?

    2. (b)

      Why would an Equal-tailed (EQT) posterior credible interval and a highest posterior density (HPD) credible interval give the same result for this posterior distribution?

    3. (c)

      For n=10 and n=100, find 95% posterior credible intervals for μ.

  4. 47.

    [Exam standard] An ornithologist is interested in the value of the mean height, μ, of the African fish eagle (Haliaeetus vocifer). The heights, X, of individual eagles have a normal distribution for which the value of the mean height μ is unknown but the standard deviation is known to be 2cm. Prior beliefs about μ can be adequately represented by a normal distribution with a mean of 68cm and a standard deviation of 1cm. A sample of 10 eagles are captured at random from the population, measured, and released, and their average height is found to be 69.5cm.

    1. (a)

      What is the posterior distribution of μ?

    2. (b)

      For both the prior and posterior distribution of μ, find the interval of length 1cm with the highest probability of containing μ. State the value of the probability associated with each interval. Comment on your results and justify any differences.

    3. (c)

      Consider the case where the number of eagles sampled, n, becomes very large. Show that the posterior for μ given the data will be Normal with mean, m1, and variance, v1 approximately given by m1≈x¯ and v12≈σ2n.
